1.content:
By the late 21st century, flying cars and android servants were being made available to the public. There were also two companies performing genetic experiments, one working on a way to stop the rapid growth of a form of the Flesh-Eating Virus. The other was working on a way to make communication between humans and other animals easier- mainly so that search dogs, and other such animals, could tell their handlers/owners what the situation was.

Sadly, the human trials portion of the tests had some very drastic outcomes- Those who had volunteered to try out the cure for the flesh-eating virus lost all sense of humanity, becoming very violent and dangerous, needing to be locked up. They also developed a craving for raw meat- any raw meat.

As for the Handlers who were testing out the human-animal communication injection- they ended up turning into humanoid versions of their partners, or any other vertebrate-type of animal they’d last been in contact with- even if it was part of their meal, or clothes- one who’d worn a set of wool socks turned into a sheep-like creature, and another who’d eaten a hamburger before the experiment turned into a cow-like creature.

The experiments were halted as a result, the vials put on ice, and the test subjects isolated from the rest of the public, with those who had tested the Flesh-Eating cure in solitary confinement, though those who had tested the animal-bonding formula were allowed to roam their complexes.

However, a group of terrorists found out about the Flesh-Eating virus experiment, and stole a vial of the “Cure”. They made some alterations, making it waterborne, and communicable, especially through saliva. They released it in several cities around the world, Europe, North America, South America, Asia, Africa, Australia, and even in the underground cities of Antarctica. The world’s militaries and health organizations could do nothing to halt the infection from being spread, until the case of John Fillard and company.

John Fillard had been a K-9 handler for the San Diego police department. In an attempt to get a closer connection to his K-9 partner, he had volunteered for the Humanimal-communication injection. Because of the injection, he ended up turning into a humanoid German shepherd. During the initial stages of the Flesh-Eaters’ Outbreak, he and the other humanimal hybrids were still at their facility when one of the scientists came in with a bite from an infected. Despite the best of efforts, others became infected. Seeing what was going on, John and other hybrids with police and military backgrounds, or with training in hand-to-hand fighting, took on the creatures, saving the remaining scientists.

By the time rescue finally came, John and most of the other hybrids who’d engaged in the fighting had been wounded by the creatures, and placed into isolation as a result. However, unlike with regular humans, they hadn’t become rabid. Subsequent testing revealed that the hybrids were immune to the Flesh Eaters’ virus, due to their own transformation. Armed with this information, the scientists went to their fellow scientists in the field of biogenetics, especially those in virology, and offered a shocking proposal- turn the humanimal injection into a contagious virus in order to save what was left of humanity. Problem was, most of the world leaders had, by this time, been either killed, infected, or had fled to some hiding place. However, most of the surviving high-ranking military officials agreed with the scientists, and gave the go-ahead. Less than a month later, the humanimal virus was released into the world. Humanity had been saved, at the cost of the human race itself- or so it seemed.

It wasn’t long before people realized that there were humans who were immune to the humanimal virus. When doctors examined their blood, they found it was due to a rare genetic mutation- of which, less than one percent of one percent of the total population had. Coincidently, these people were immune to the Flesh Eaters’ virus.

It is now the 23rd century, and the undead outnumber the living by at least two to one. The surviving human population is largely immune to the viruses. The war against the undead is at a standstill- the armed forces are having trouble retaking the land for the living, especially in the Arctic regions. The military forces, and scientists, are currently searching for a way to finally win the war- like better weapons and tactics, or something that speeds the decomposition of zombies.

Most cities are built like fortresses- stone walls around the urban areas, at least twenty feet in thickness, and at least twenty feet high. One of the requirements most cities have is that each person over the age of 18 is to spend at least week on wall duty- watching for others, and to maintain the wall itself. As for armament, the Weekly Guards are armed with crossbow-type weapons, while the Professionals are armed with bolt and lever style firearms. For close-up work, a special shovel-ax is used mainly, though there are other items.

Then there are the Nomads. They wander the area, acting mostly as a mixture of Scout and Traders between the cities. They are armed with a mix of weapons.

Of course, there is also bandits, which are highly dangerous.

Now, who is the person the future follows?

Numerous small scars covered its half-naked body. Milky-white orbs gazed hungrily in Braewerth's direction. Braewerth raised a dictaphone to his mouth.

"Subject Zero-Zero-One appears to have been female before infection, as is indicated by both the lack of male genitalia and the resultant wounds that would occur with the removal of said genitalia. S.C. Stevens set up a block of wood and put the crossbow target on it. Then he took the Handle Extension from Lucas and smashed the target with it. He then inspected the D-Handle. "At least your father knew what he was teaching when he taught you how to maintain your weapons- this end's good and tight." He then looked at the connector section- it was a screw-type. "Threads are clean- do you have the right grease to make sure that the two parts screw together smoothly?"

"Yes sir, I do," Lucas said.

"That's a plus- some new Weekly Guards don't even have the stuff, let alone actually use it." He then picked up the ax-shovel section, and inspected the blades. "Good and sharp," he said. He then picked up the crossbow, and looked at it. "Got another target and bolt?"

Lucas went and got a target and a bolt.

"When I tell you, toss it in the air," Stevens said as he drew the cord back to the holding grove. He took the bolt and put it in the slot. "Alright, toss the target." Lucas tossed the target ten feet into the air. Stevens lifted the crossbow, and pulled the trigger. The bolt pierced the target, and buried itself in Lucas's fence. "Apologies about the fence, but you're right on with the crossbow- good and smooth action, and it isn't going to just release the bolt on you. Hard to get that combination."

"Thanks sir, I use it as often as I can," Lucas smiled. "I got a lion friend who has trouble hunting- messed himself up when he was playing sports- really bad tackle."

"That was obvious when you tried the Woodcutters' Chop," Steven's chuckled. "Never use that in a battle against either bandits or the undead- gets you killed either way. I don't want to go to your family and tell them that you got your throat torn out because of a rookie mistake."

"So, what do you recommend?"

"Smack! Slice! Stab! and Smash!," Stevens said with a smile. "Smack them to the ground with the flat of the blades. Slice their arms and legs off with with the edges. Put the two parts together and stab the neck with the shovel point, severing the head from the rest of the body. Finally, smash the skull with the D-handle during Disposal. Simple, fairly quick when properly executed, and always effective."

1321111112.title: Ticking Time Bomb

13211111121.content:
"We'll deal with that if it comes," the SC said with a chuckle. Then his face became hard. "Until then, I expect you to listen to my commands. Be at the East Wall at Zero Five Hundred hours, on the Dot! If you're late, you'll be scrubbing out the latrines with a toothbrush for your duration of Wall Duty!"

"Yes Sir!" Lucas said as he gave a quick salute.

"Good," said Stevens. "See you at the wall." With that, the man walked back out on the road, and went down the street.

Lucas gave a sigh as he lowered his hand. He then picked up his weapons, and went back inside to get something to eat. As he went to the kitchen, he looked into his father's Shrine Room. Making a slight detour, he went inside, and noticed that his mother was already in there. The mare was setting up some incense.

"I noticed that the Section Commander came by," she said as she lit the incense. "Is it your tour of Duty?"

"It is mother," Lucas said as he sat on a special pad. He looked at the Shrine- there was three rows; a picture of his father, a magnificent looking stallion, was in the center, at the top was an urn containing his ashes, and at the bottom was his sword- one based on a Scottish claymore. Only a Professional Soldier, former or current, was allowed to own a sword, or their family if they died.

He looked at his mother and noticed that she had a slight smile on her face. "He'd be proud to know that you were going to serve on the wall," she said as she sat down. "He and that Stephanie were good friends- that man would even visit me when I was sick and your father was unable to visit in person. As it is, I had wanted to marry him when I was doing two years in the Service."

"He told me that he was unimmune," Lucas said. "So how would that work out?"

Ms. Willow chuckled. "A way would have been found, such as artificial insemination," she said. "As it is, he is married to a wolf, and they have two daughters around your age- one's a wolf, and the other's a born human."

"Adopted?"

"Biological- they used a doctor to help get his wife pregnant with his children," Ms. Willow said. "The born human one is immune just to let you know- and she's looking for a boyfriend from what I hear."

"I'll find my own girlfriend, mother," Lucas said with a chuckle. "By the way, why didn't you marry him instead of Father?"

"Truth is, your father won me in a fight," Ms. Willow said with a chuckle. "Both of them had wanted to marry me, and I told your father that the only way I'd marry him, was if he could take Stephanie in a fight- that human is very good at CQC. The two of them had a boxing match, under the guise of training of course. Took your father seven rounds to exhaust Stephanie enough to forfeit the match. Funny thing is, after Stephanie left the ring, your father collapsed. Still, the two of them remained good friends afterwards."

"Never saw him around here when Father was alive," said Lucas.

"He wasn't a Section Commander until a couple of years back," said Ms. Willow. "Your father saved his life you should know- countless times. Saved him on the day he was killed too."

"You don't need to remind me," Lucas said with a sigh. A swarm of the undead had came to the area, and all had been needed on the Wall- including those who'd been Off Duty. The fighting had lasted three days, and even he'd taken part- in that he was helping to cook meals, and care for those who'd been wounded, though there was always an armed guard by the bitten humans- just in case. It was the first time he'd seen the creatures- they were scarier than the stories described them. He also saw his father get killed- got his throat torn out. Didn't matter what you were- an injury there was highly fatal.

"You'll be fine," said Ms. Willow. "Stephanie wouldn't put a new guard in a really dangerous position unless he was short on people. The Brass wouldn't allow it anyway- they'd have him hung if he did something that foolish."

"I guess that's good to know," Lucas said as he stood up.

Ms. Willow smiled. "He's a good man to know, and one you can trust with your life. Now go get yourself something to eat, and I'll see about packing your clothes. I'll make sure that you've got plenty of clean underwear."

"Mother," Lucas groaned as he left the room.
13211111121.title: Remembering

132111111211.content:
Lucas found himself without a blanket at four the next morning.

"You'd best get out of bed because you're not seeing this blanket, or that mattress, for the next seven days," Ms. Willow said as she folded the blanket up.

Lucas groaned as he sat up. "Couldn't I have had five more minutes?"

"No," said his mother. "If you're not at the Wall at five, you'll be stuck washing it for the next week."

"Why won't I be able to use my own bed?" Lucas asked. "Our house isn't even ten minutes from the Wall. I mean, father came home every now and then."

"Yes, but that's because he was an Officer," said Ms. Willow. "You're just a Wall Guard- you have to stay with your unit, unless there's an emergency. Should something happen at the Wall, they'll want every guard on Duty at his post at the Soonest! And as you know full well, if something happened during the day, your father didn't come home."

"What about you mother?" Lucas asked. "You've been home during the evenings, especially when Richie has his bouts." Richie was his younger brother by five years. When he was five years old, Richie was taken to the doctors with a severe coughing fit- he was diagnosed with Double Pneumonia, and his lungs had never fully recovered as a result, even when the sickness itself had passed.

"That's one of those Emergencies," Ms. Willow said with a sigh- she'd never forgiven herself for letting Richie play in the rain that day- it had been very cold.

"I'm sorry to bring it up mom," sighed Lucas. He cared for his little brother- if there was anything he could do to help him, he'd do it in a heartbeat.

"I know," Ms. Willow said. "And this is why we must do this- as long as one of us serves on the Wall, we can afford to pay for the medicines he needs."

Lucas looked at his mother- as long as one of them served, the Town Guard would help pay for any medical bills, and college expenses that one had, and then some. And the medicines that Richie needed were highly expensive. Then again, they couldn't afford to Skip guard duty, which was to pay Double the month's Taxes, though, thankfully, one couldn't keep on Skipping their Duty anyways- they'd have to work two weeks on the Wall the next year to make up for the week Skipped, in addition to the Double Tax.

He then went and got ready- taking a warm shower. When he was done, he combed his mane and tail with a great fondness- They'd be trimmed within a few hours- part of the rules for Guard Duty was that short hair was a must- kept the zed heads from grabbing you and jerking you off balance. His father had always kept his mane and tail short as he was in the Professional Core, while his mother grew her's out, and would come home from Duty with a trimmed mane and tail.

He finished getting dressed, and went to eat breakfast- warm oatmeal with brown sugar and maple syrup. He went to his father's Shrine, said a quick prayer, asking for safety while he did his duty, went to the door, and put his uniform on. The uniform was resistant to tears and bullets, and even bolts, but it didn't stop them from potentially injuring or killing someone, though the odds were greatly reduced. However, if a zed had you in its grips, it could still break bones, or tear limbs off, and one's throat was one area that was tricky to protect. He then put his pack on, which had a few changes of clothes, in case he was allowed to leave the Wall for a period of time, and held a quiver of a dozen bolts, and he'd had his crossbow attached to it. He then placed the shovel-ax in its holster on his left hip, with the blades covered, and placed the Handle Extension in its holster on his right, with the D-handle ready to be used.

"You look just like your father when I first saw him," Ms. Willow said as she gave him a quick hug and kiss. "Big, tall, strong, and ready for anything. See you home in a week son."

"I'll see you to," Lucas said as he held onto the mare. "Give Richie my best." He then let go of the woman, and walked out the door.

As he walked down the sidewalk, he saw his lion friend come out in his wheelchair. "Hey Sam," Lucas said, as he walked to the edge of the lawn. "What are you doing up so early?"

"I noticed that the S.C. came by yesterday," Sam said with a sigh. Ever since his tackle, he'd lost the use of his legs- along with his control of everything from the waist on down. "He even paid me a visit, and told me that you were going to be doing Wall Duty for the next week."

"So you came out to wish me luck right?" Lucas asked.

Sam smiled and said....
132111111211.title: Early Morning

1321111112112.content:
Lucas blinked when he realized that his friend was wearing the uniform of a Wall Guard, and had his weapons and armor stowed in, or on, various parts of his chair. "Sam, you do realize that you are on the Exempt list."

Sam chuckled. "That's why I want to do it. I want to show people that I can do the job."

"Sam, you know you can't exactly fight like the average person can," Lucas chuckled.

Sam pointed at his crossbow. "I've been a better shot than you were since we was kids- my eyes are still good, as are my arms," he said. "I figure I can be in the Lookout towers, and pick off those zeds before they come within a hundred yards."

"And if you can't get that post?" Lucas asked.

"I'll do whatever else they give me," Sam said. "I'll make bolts for the crossbows- it would free up a two-legged person for patrolling and fighting."

Lucas chuckled. Sam was on the Exempt List due to his injury- those who were disabled, injured, sick, pregnant, or owned businesses didn't have to do Wall Duty, but more often than not, they'd find a way to help out, even if it was something as simple as cooking for the others- with many business owners actually having one of their employees manage shop while they served out a week. With Sam, it was also a matter of Family Pride- even before the undead started walking, there'd been someone in the family serving in the military in some capacity. About the only ones who didn't serve were the sick, and they were often given a Make-up week to serve when they were fully recovered.

"Alright Sam," Lucas said with a smile. "I'll help push you to the Wall."

Sam smiled. "Saves my arms some work." He placed his arms on his lap while Lucas got behind him, held onto the handles, and begin to push his friend's chair.

13211111121121.content:
As Lucas pushed his friend, he noticed plenty of others getting ready to start their days, saw the lampmen coming out to check on the streetlights, heard showers running, smelled breakfasts being cooked, and even saw other Guards, both Weekly and Professional, heading towards the Wall.

"Come on," Sam said. "I don't want to be late for Duty."

"I'd be the one Late for Duty," Lucas said with a chuckle. "They'd just say, 'Glad to have you with us Sam Larens,' to you. To me, they'd probably say, 'I hope you like feathers, because you'll be making flights for bolts all week.' After all, I'm required to be there, you don't have to."

"Still, I want to be on time," said Sam.

"Yes, but I don't want to bust one of your wheels," Lucas said, as the chair squeaked along. "You might want to request a new chair when we get there. It would make things easier."

Lucas shook his head. In some ways, especially on a technological level, society had regressed centuries, with electricity being reserved for special situations, such as lighting the streets. Even the armament that Guards used was more Medieval than Modern. Even the firearms that the Professional Core used had its roots based on those made between the late 19th and early 21st centuries. Laser-using firearms had been available to the police and military in the late 21st and early 22nd centuries, but the energy coils for them required a certain amount of maintenance, far more than that required for projectile firearms, which had, thankfully, still been available and produced. However, those were now restricted to the Professional Core and Full-time Police officers, as it required a certain level of skill to make the barrels for them, along with the bullets. Thankfully, crossbows were fairly easy to make, same with the bolts.

"They weren't just murdered, they were raped," said Jackson. "And not only that, they were partway eaten- and it wasn't a deadhead that did it. The police found him covered in blood, and when they pumped his stomach, the police found the women's flesh. Couldn't get any clearer than that unless they caught him in the act."

Lucas watched as the hangman slipped a hood over the cheetah's head, along with a noose. The hangman then walked to a set of levers, and looked at an open window, where the Judge was watching. The Judge gave a nod, and the hangman pulled a leaver, releasing the catch on the trapdoor that the cheetah was standing over, still trying to free himself as he fell through. Lucas heard the Snap! of the man's neck breaking when the rope reached it's end, and he felt sick to his stomach.

Jackson took a look at him. "He isn't worth you losing your breakfast over. Try and keep it down."

Lucas gave a slow nod, and swallowed what little had came up.

Jackson pointed toward some benches. "Take a seat- I'll go set up his funeral arrangements- though if I had things my way, I'd toss his good-for-nothing carcass over the wall and be done with it- he always caused trouble- fighting, stealing, and more. Still, he's family, and the rest want him buried in the family plot at any rate."

Lucas nodded and walked over to the bench. As he sat down, he noticed that a human woman about his age was sitting next to him, holding onto a necklace.

"I'm glad that monster's dead," she muttered. "My sister can rest in peace knowing that her killer was brought to justice."
13211111121121111121.title: "He's my kin."

132111111211211111211.content:
"I'm sorry for your loss," Lucas said.

"Only survived that monster's attack because my sister tossed me into the dirty clothes bin," the woman said. "If he'd of done anything to me, I'd end up looking like him."

Lucas took another look at her, and noticed that she was wearing clothes made from plant and synthetic fibers, with gloves on her hands- clear indicators that she didn't have immunity to the viruses. He also noticed her blue eyes, and her blond hair.

"I doubt you'd of looked like him," Lucas said. "You're too beautiful to end up as ugly as him."

The woman chuckled. "You're nice, but you know you've got no chance with me, not if I wish to remain human."

"That's alright," Lucas said. "I'm sure you'll find the right person."

"Of course, we could be friends," the woman said as she placed her gloved hand on Lucas's brown furred hand. "I'm Sashta Travels."

"Lucas Willow. Currently I'm stationed at the East Wall."

"I figured," Sashta said as she patted a patch on his shoulder. "The Morning Bird's a clear indicator of that."

Lucas took a look at the patch. "Always thought that it was a dove, or a pidgin."

"I like to think of it as a bird of Hope," Sashta said. "I long for the day I can swim in a creek without a protective suit, without worrying if I'll turn into the Dead, or something that's part animal."

"You know I'm a horse right?"

"Yes, but I'd like to be able to hold the hands of the people I meet," Sashta said. "Perhaps even kiss a good looking man every so often. Maybe spend the night in their bed. I want to be able to do that, and not worry about turning, and end up changing my diet. If he'd of had his way with me, and I'd survived, I'd of had to give up eating apples." She then began crying.

"I've been where you are," Lucas said with a sigh. "My father was killed in front of me."

"Did he die protecting you?" Sashta asked.

Lucas nodded, as his mind flashed back to that tragic day.

The last snapping head had been smashed in, with the remains being tossed into a big old bonfire. His father had decided to come to the infirmary, to see him and his mother. Problem was, one of the bitten humans had proven to be Unimmune, and they'd Turned, killing the guard responsible for putting him down. He'd come for them then, and would have killed Lucas if his father hadn't pushed him out of the way, and grappled with the creature. The Turned human bit him in the throat, and tore out his jugular, just as his mother smashed his skull in with an IV pole. Lucas had tried to stop the bleeding with his hands, but it had proven too much. Colonel William Willow had been buried with full Military Honors, including a 21 gun salute, in tribute not only to him, but all the others who'd lost their lives in the fighting.

Lucas shock his head back in the Present. "Sorry. I don't like bringing it up myself."

Sashta chuckled. "Least we have something in common."
132111111211211111211.title: Lucas starts talking to her

1321111112112111112111.content:
"Got the funeral all arranged for that worthless piece of garbage."

Lucas looked up and saw Jackson coming towards them. "Everything's taken care of?"

"All except tossing dirt in his face and pissing on his grave," Jackson said with a growl as he looked back at the gallows, where the condemned cheetah still hanged, though the two big guards were ducking under it, both to check to see if he was dead, and to take him down. He then looked at Sashta. "Anything you need, the family will help provide it."

Sashta stood up, and looked at him. "How about we start with my family." She then walked off.

"Can't blame her."

"What?" Lucas asked.

"Can't blame her for wanting her family back," Jackson said. "I hope that she'll find a group to care for her."

"I hope so," Lucas said.

"And you'd better keep your hands to yourself if you run into her, or another Unimmune human who's without protective clothing," Jackson said.

"Yes sir," Lucas muttered.

"It's for your own good," Jackson said. "If you Turn her, she'd be your responsibility."

"So I've heard."

"It would be just like taking care of a child," Jackson said. "Actually, taking care of a child would be easier; they wouldn't complain about how things used to be."

"Understood," said Lucas. "That and she'd have to go to Instinct Control classes."

Jackson chuckled. "I remember mine; trying to sit on my legs while a bunch of antelope ran circles around me was not easy."

"Barking dogs," Lucas said with a nervous chuckle.

Jackson smiled. "Alright, we still have supplies to get."

"Okay."

They then went towards the
1321111112112111112111.title: Jackson comes back

13211111121121111121111.content:
Soon enough, Lucas heard the striking of hammers against metal. "We're here for weapons?" he asked.

Jackson nodded. "Two swords."

"You mean?"

"That's right, two Recruits will be inducted into the Professional Core tonight." Jackson knocked on the door of a long stone house, from where the sounds of men and women grunting could be heard. "Bladesmith! This is Corporal Jackson of the East Wall. Those swords done?"

The door opened, and an elephant man ducked on outside of the house. He took a few deep breaths, and looked at Jackson. "They are almost done," he said in a deep voice. Then he sneezed, his trunk making the sound of a dull trumpet. "Sorry, smoke got in the nozzle again."

Jackson chuckled. "But they are just about done?"

"Wife's putting the final touches to them," the bladesmith said. "Please, come in, Slowpoke."

"You can only call me that when you're in uniform, Wiggles."

The elephant chuckled, his nose moving all over the place. "I did my two years in the Service; I can call you Splochy if I want."

"Splochy!" The fur on the back of Jackson's neck started to rise. "I'll have you know that these are Spots, not Sploches!"

The elephant laughed. "My eyes say differently." He then ducked back inside, and handed a couple of squares of wet cloths. "Use them to keep yourselves from breathing in the smoke."

Jackson carefully tied one around his face, only his eyes showing. He looked at Lucas, who was busy covering his long nose. "Need any help?"

"I'm good," Lucas said, as he finished tying. The two of them walked inside,

"Tina," the Elephnat bellowed over the pounding of hammers. "Those important clients are here!"

"Another five minutes," said a shrill voice.

As Lucas's eyes adjusted to the smoke, he saw...
13211111121121111121111.title: Weapons section

132111111211211111211111.content:
A four foot tall mouse woman was swinging a hammer, pounding on the heated metal.

"I hope that isn't one of the swords you've got for me," said Jackson.

Tina turned her head. "I'm not that foolish," she said. "They're cooling over there."

Lucas turned, and saw the blades, which had a slight yellow glow. He walked up to them.

"Don't you dare touch those swords," roared the Bladesmith. "You burn your hands, and you'll be in deep trouble for messing with them before they were ready."

"I just wanted to look," Lucas said.

"Then use your eyes, and not your hands," said Tina. The mouse resumed pounding.

Lucas looked at the blades and saw that....
132111111211211111211111.title: A Mouse

1321111112112111112111111.content:
The swords were extremely different; the one was a short double-bladed sword, at around a foot in length. The other one had a long curve, was very wide, had only one sharpened edge, and was at least four feet in length.

"A gladius and a talwar," the Bladesmith said. "Perfect weapons for a small shrew and a large African elephant."

"The inductees chose their own, right?" Jackson asked.

"Of course, can't make a sword for someone if the sword won't fit them," said the Bladesmith. "I'm surprised you're not wearing your kris; my father made that wavy blade special for you."

"Had it under my pillow when I went to bed last night," Jackson said. "Had a bad dream, so I don't plan on carrying it for a day or two."

The Bladesmith laughed, his trunk wobbling around in the air. "A professional soldier not carrying his sword because of a bad dream; that's a good one."

Tina snorted at this. "Horty, don't laugh at him; the true kris is said to have been possessed by spirits, both good ones, and bad ones. If he thinks that carrying it will give him bad luck at the moment, he's better off wielding one of those common shaxes, like one of the Weekly Guard. I'll wager he'll carry it in a few days though."

"What is the wager?" Horty asked.

"We'll see how good you are with that trunk," Tina said. "If he's wearing the sword in two days, you have to dust the whole house with nothing but your nose and a feather duster. However, if he still has it in his quarters when he comes by, we'll see how good that thing is in bed."

"Deal," said Horty.

Jackson chuckled. "I don't know if I should carry it or not."

"Don't and I'll tell you the details," Horty whispered.

"Do, and I'll tell you the details about his attempt to dust those blades he keeps," Tina said. "Those things aren't easy to keep clean."

"We'll see," said Jackson. "Just make sure to let us know when the blades are done; the ceremony will be tonight."

Horty nodded. "Will do."

Lucas and Jackson step outside, and removed the wet cloths. They resumed walking through town.

"Little warm in there," Lucas said.

"They do good work," Jackson said. "I'd trust their steel over most other bladesmiths. My kris has saved my life plenty of times."

"Then why aren't you carrying it?" Lucas asked. "My father carried his claymore everywhere he went, especially while in uniform."

"It's unlucky at the moment."

"Unlucky?"

"When you chose a sword, you must know the history of it; traditionally, when one owned a kris, they'd sleep with it under their pillow. If they had a good dream, good luck would come. A bad dream though means bad luck instead."

"That's silly," said Lucas.

"I'll tell you what's silly," Jackson grabbed Lucas by the collar. "Not being at your post on time. We have to get to the West side, and run the rest of the way, if you wish to be back at your post by eight hundred! Do you hear me?"

"Sir, yes sir!"

"Good. Now let's pick up the pace a bit; don't want anyone thinking we're pussyfooting about."
1321111112112111112111111.title: They were very different.

1321111221.content:
The Section Commander that stood before Lucas was dressed in the unmistakable Town Militia uniform. He was an anthro, just like Willow, only he was a canid—a coyote. He stood with his paws behind his back, tall and firm, tail unmoving, muzzle raised up, behind which a pair of pale-green eyes pierced Lucas with razor sharp scrutiny. Holstered to the coyote's right hip was a Bren Ten semi-auto pistol while his melee weapon of choice, a crowbar of all things, was strapped across his back just above his tail.

Lucas nearly jumped at the sudden realization of his presence, quickly snapping to attention and throwing a salute to the officer.

"Sir, Lucas Willow reporting for evaluation of standard-issue civilian weaponry, Sir!"

"At ease, Mr. Willow; you are not under my command yet," the SC informed Lucas with an amused smile, "and I'm here off-duty as well, though I am pleased to see you so eager to become a week-long warrior."

"Sir, my father was a professional soldier in the defensive lines against the undead. I just want to follow in his footsteps, sir!" Lucas was so excited, he did not put himself at ease despite his officers order.

"Well, you can start by addressing me as Section Commander Taylor," the SC replied with pat on Lucas's arm, somewhat alleviated the horse's anxiety, "but just Taylor will do just fine, for now."

Lucas shifted his hooves, still nervous before SC Taylor's stature that measure inches below his own, but was no less intimidating, his visage speaking for itself, but the coyote's body was also filled out quite well, muscles strong, firm and quick with the imperfection on his coat of fur speaking volumes of his experience along with his ribbons displayed on his chest.

"Yes, Section Commander Taylor."

Taylor exhaled through his nostrils with a sigh. "let's take a look at your weapons, Lucas isn't it?"

"Yes, Section Commander Taylor."

A few minutes passed as Taylor inspected Willow's tools of self preservation, marginally impressed by their exceptional upkeep, but gave a scowl at the pristine condition of the blade and bow. Upon being asked whether he had ever practiced, Willow answered that his father would always teach him with his own weapons, hence the lack of wear on Lucas's crossbow and shovelaxe. Taylor nodded thoughtfully at his answer and finished his inspection, returning Lucas his crossbow and shovelaxe for which he excused himself from Taylor to set on the outside table before quickly returning.

"It's a damn shame that you probably won't be using them," Taylor said with his amused smile back on his muzzle.

"What do you mean, Section Commander Taylor?" Lucas asked in confusion.

"Lucas, usually the Weekly Guards receive weapons inspections in mass upon reporting to the Town Militia HQ," the coyote began, "I'll get back to those troops once the squad is assembled by oh-two-hundred. You, on the other paw, are a special case. One I need to have prepared by tomorrow, that is if you decide to accept the commission." Taylor paused to pull and envelope from his pocket. Lucas was about speak, but was silenced when Taylor continued. "When you registered yourself to the Town's Militia you had made quite a effort to qualify yourself for being tasked for assignments set abroad. I have to tell ya, kid, it's not that often that they send people around the globe when towns have got enough on their plates with the undead, and those assignments usually go to bigger boys than yourself. Consider yourself the name pulled out of a hat for this one." With that he handed Lucas the envelope.

Lucas's fingers trembling with excitement gingerly took the paper from Taylor's extended paw. This time it did not smell like scented paper, but like the sharp and unpleasant chemicals of freshly laid inks and adhesives. This was important stuff.

"Do you mean...? I've been chosen...?"

Taylor's smile just stayed plastered on his muzzle, pulling just a bit more at the corners of his lips as he nodded to the equine. Lucas did not hesitate to rip open the letter. He was not sick of home, he loved his town, but finally, he was going to see the world, finally his runs could take him somewhere beyond the four walls that separated the living from the undead. One so sheltered as Lucas would find something profoundly poetic in the feel of foreign wind blowing through his mane as he would stand on a cliff facing an open ocean, sunny canyons, the vast expanses of. . .
1321111221.title: A Change of Plans

choices: Won't get this chance again; go for it!
13211112211.content:
Section Commander Taylor chuckled at Willow's reaction.

"Because of your performance in advanced placement biology classes, you're to be the assistant to Chief Biologist Richard Brady at the outpost Big Magnet of the fourth Antarctic research division for the entirety of the coming winter. You'll be one of fourteen personnel at the outpost including their helicopter pilot, who is flying out early tomorrow and who you'll be joining."

Lucas could only stammer syllables as he wanted to complain, but there was nothing the section commander could do about it other than disapprove of his misplaced thanklessness. It was obvious to Taylor what Lucas's feelings were on the matter, so he stepped right into the ultimatum:

"This assignment is only your choice, Mr. Willow, those papers in the envelope need to be signed and turned into the Town Militia HQ or directly to City Hall, by twenty-one-hundred tonight."

Taylor turned to leave making his way towards the sidewalk. Taylor looked at Willow once more and added, "You don't have a night to sleep on the issue, so I suggest you think on it carefully before you turn your nose up at a ticket to leave the city walls in relative safety. When you turn in those papers, expect at your front door at seven-hundred tomorrow. If you don't," Taylor paused as if shrugging mentally due to his look of apathy, "then report to Town Militia HQ like all other weekly recruits. Seven-hundred sharp."

With that the coyote left with a brisk pace, disappearing around the nearest corner as he headed back to base.

Man, Lucas did want to go out and see the world, but Antarctica? That was nowhere near the top of his list. The constant sub-zero temperatures would mean no feeling of the breeze in his mane unless he wanted to suffer frostbite from the windchill, the deep snow and the need to keep bundled would hinder his running, and the scenery would always have to be enjoyed while snow-blind. Just the though of being unable to step more than a few meter outside was making him feel claustrophobic. The ant-hive tunnels of the cities still had nothing compared to the open. What was worse was that the further he read the more he found that Big Magnet was not part of one of the cities, not even close. Thirty crew maximum base, eight-hundred mile from nearest civilization, two hundred to the next nearest station, and twelve-hundred miles from the coast. Middle of the forsaken nowhere.

What to do?
13211112211.title: See the Cold, Dead World

132111122111.content:
Lost in thought, Lucas wandered in circles around his backyard while reading over the papers detailing his commission that he held if front of him as he walked. Aside from all the fine print reading, there really wasn't much to fill out, just a few general questions regarding the equipment that was to be issued and few places that required his signature. It was so simple yet so difficult to make this decision that Lucas was giving himself a headache before he even realized just how hungry he was after his run. He could not think about a decision like this on an empty stomach, let alone with a headache.

Lucas stuffed the papers into the front pocket of his shorts and retrieved his equipment from the table, holding his crossbow with one had an the shovelaxe under the same arm as he headed inside his home, making his way to the kitchen. The sound of running water could be heard once he opened the door. His mother was there, her back turned towards him as she was busying herself with washing the dishes. Lucas licked his lips when he saw the sliced bread and an assortment of veggies ready on the counter, perfect for a delicious sandwich. Taking the shovelaxe into his free hand, Lucas made his way tenderly towards the kitchen table, trying to suppress the clip-clop of his hoofs on hardwood as much as possible. With arms outstretched, he had almost made it when his mother, without even looking at him, said:

"Lucas, please don't put your weapons on the table. Put them back in your room if you are done playing."

His arms sagged in defeat as he let out a groan. She must have known him too well to have such an intuition. Lucas quickly navigated up the stairs and just dropped his weapons on the bed before hurrying back to the kitchen, nearly slipping down the steps.

"You really shouldn't run in the house," Ms. Willow chastised once Lucas was layering greens on a wholegrain slice of bread.

"I'm sorry, but I just get so restless," Lucas said somewhat evasively. He did get restless while cooped up, but he'd just been outside. What was really bothering him was that trip to Antarctica, those papers stuffed down his pocket. He was almost sure that he wanted to burn them in the fireplace and take his place on the City Wall, to serve his town in a way that mattered. The only thing that held him back was. . .

"I heard you talking to someone outside just a moment ago," his mother interrupted his thoughts. "Who was out there with you, Lucas?"

"It was only the Section Commander, mother," Lucas replied. "He came by to inspect my Town Militia issued weapons."

"Oh?" Ms. Willow's voice held no surprise. "Is it time to serve your week on Wall Duty?"

"Not exactly," Lucas muttered, resenting what he was about to bring up.

"What do you mean?" his mother inquired, without taking her eyes off her work.

Lucas took a deep breath. "The application that I sent in to get a chance to serve abroad has come back to me with a commission." He let a moment pass, letting that sink in before he continued, "But it's not anywhere that I wanted to go. They gave me a chance to go to Antarctica."

Ms. Willow shut the water off and turned to her son. "To Antarctica?" she balked.

"I know, but it's only a choice," Lucas breathed a sigh. "I really wanted to see the world, but this commission, it's sending me to the underside of the Earth for the entire summer, to a cold and desolate place! I. . .I don't think I'm going to accept the commission. They might not consider me again, but I really don't think this is worth it." Lucas watched his mother as she looked at him vacantly. Suddenly her gaze shifted up, betraying a hint of rage directed at someone or something not in the room, and then she turned back to the sink.

"The Section Commander, he was not. . ." Ms. Willow began, but paused as if holding something back. "He must have been the officer that had just transferred in."

"I don't know mother," Lucas answered, "but I haven't seen him before, on the wall or leading patrols. He was a coyote and a decorated soldier."

A few moments passed between them, Lucas awaiting a reply from his mother who only stared absently ahead of her out the window. "Of course Stephanie wouldn't bring such news;" Ms. Willow chuckled to herself, her eyes glancing sullenly at her son, "that Stephanie always resented anyone leaving, and since it is you, well. . ." She trailed off, lost in her musing. Lucas could have asked who was this Stephanie of which his mother spoke, but more importantly he saw the reasons that the person would have to resent his departure.

"Mother, what would father have wanted?" Lucas asked slowly.

The mare turned to back him, staring as if almost unsure of how to answer his question, but a moment later a look spread on her face that told Lucas just how she felt on the matter. She was going to be. . .
132111122111.title: So Far Away

1321111221111.content:
Ms. Willow smiled at her son. "Oh, Lucas," she placed her hands on his shoulders, "your father was a very brave stallion. In fact, many would say that he was too brave and did stupid things, but he would always pull through, no matter what he got himself into." She got misty eyes as memories flooded her mind, the sad truth to the inaccuracy of her last statement. She let go before she continued. "He would be gone for weeks at a time, sometimes entire months, and I would be worried sick about him, but I always knew that he would come back to me." Tears started to form in her eyes.

"Mother, I'm sorry, I didn't mean to bring up sad memories," Lucas apologized for making her cry.

"No, don't be sorry, Lucas," she sniffed, wiping the tears away, "they are sad memories, but they are the good ones. I'm sure you'll make good memories wherever you'll go, and whenever your gone, your absence will make my heart grow fonder of you and the memory of your coming home will bring, just like they did with your father."

"Mother, are you saying...?" Lucas began, feeling his eyes welling up.

"Take the commission Lucas," Ms. Willow caressed her son's cheek and smiled. "You asked me what your father would have wanted, and he would have wanted you to go and see the world. You might not get another chance. And if you do a good job, I'm sure they'll send your someplace warm and sunny next time, okay?"

"Alright, mother," Lucas choked back his emotions as he saw that his other had already gained her composure.

"Make sure to fill out those papers and tell everyone you know by the end of today. I'm sure that prick of a new guy doesn't know everyone in the neighborhood and wouldn't even tell 'em if he did, so you've got a job to do."

"I'm on it right away!" Lucas dashed out the door, but not before his mother called out behind him.

"I'll make sure to pack your warmest sweaters for you!"

"Mom!"
1321111221111.title: Encouraging

13211112211112.content:
Standing outside in the early morning, Lucas waited for the Section Commander to arrive like he said that he would. Lucas was dressed in blue jeans that extended all the way down to his hooves and a navy blue kangaroo-pocket sweat shirt with a longsleeve underneath to deal with the nippy summer mornings. It wasn't something that would not have been be appreciated if he were attending the Wall Guard, but for his journey to the Antarctic, his casual clothing was acceptable as long as he would wear the issued thermal wear under and over it. In his left hand he held a duffle bag filled with a supply of light casual wear, personal hygiene items, notebooks and binders filled with notes from his previous biology classes and a textbook to go along with them that would certainly come in handy. Just the bare minimum. Other than that he brought along his shovelaxe and crossbow just in case.

As far as personal effects were concerned, Lucas clutched a switchblade in his other hand. He would often lift it up to examine it's design. Six inches of sharp steel resting within a cherry handle with a gold plated guard and pommel. On the pommel, two letters etched into the metal displayed the initials of the previous owner, W. W. His father's initials. Lucas's mother had given him his father's trusty old knife as a parting gift for good luck last night. She was not out with him this morning, seemingly for the difficulty of saying goodbye to the son she would not to see again for the next quarter of a year. He placed the knife into his pocket and continued waiting.

It was seven o'clock exactly and Lucas was beginning to think that maybe they had lost his commission papers or maybe this new Section Commander wasn't as punctual as he should have been, when he heard the sound of a running engine. Looking to his left, Lucas spotted a single vehicle moving on the empty street. It was an olive colored light utility vehicle from the US Army of the 22nd century with the Town Militia insignia painted onto the door. By the sound it made, Lucas could tell that it still utilized an internal combustion engine and rubber tires instead of the modern diffusion drives. To be fair, a diffusion drive's upkeep would have been impossible in the state of the world today, however, it was possible to synthesize fossil fuels. The car pulled up alongside Lucas's home, in the driver's seat sat the coyote known as Section Commander Taylor.

"Hop in, son," Taylor called Lucas over from the car's open cabin.

Lucas walked over and set his bag and both weapons into the backseat of the military vehicle before taking his seat on the passenger side. Taylor glanced back at all that Lucas had with him and even tested the weight of the bag, and remembering the weight of the weapons, he calculated the total in his head. Personnel traveling to Antarctica were only allowed a certain weight in personal items. Lucas, however, had packed very lightly Taylor noted, probably because he didn't know what to expect.

"We're going to make another stop in town," said Taylor as they took off down the street, "pick up the pilot, he's right over by the West Wall."

"Who is this pilot anyway?" Lucas asked. "How come he is not with the Town Militia?"

"The pilot is a friend of mine, I'll introduce you once we're there," Taylor answered while negotiating a turn. "As for why he is not with the Town Militia, it's because he is a war veteran. Vets don't have to serve weeks on the wall if they don't want to."

"We've got plenty of vets serving on the Wall Guard," Lucas spun, "why is this guy freeloading?"

"He's only been here a few weeks," Taylor stated, "getting ready for the assignment in Antarctica. He only stayed longer because the mayor of this town paid him to fly you out."

"And what about you?" Lucas raised an eyebrow.

"Just a coincidence that I transferred in at the same time," Taylor replied matter-of-factly. "Besides, I like growing communities like this," Taylor gestured to the buildings passing by.

A few minutes passed as they traveled a distance the would have taken half an hour on foot. They stopped next to a tall building with an external structure of iron stairs leading only partway up with the access to the roof being a retracted ladder at the top.

"Grab your stuff and let's go up," said Taylor as he stepped out of the car. "The helicopter is on the roof and McCoy's also got the penthouse."

Lucas gathered up his stuff when he thought to ask, "Who's McCoy? Is he the pilot?" It was the only name SC Taylor had mentioned besides his own.

"Yep," Taylor affirmed. He was saving the rest of his introduction for once they met this McCoy. Lucas followed Taylor to the top of the stairs where he knocked on a door next to the retracted ladder. Lucas could hear some shuffling around inside, but apparently it was not fast enough for Taylor who banged thrice on the door with his fist.

"Hold on!" bawled a voice from inside, mumbling the next part which both of the anthro's sensitive ears could pick up, ". . .for fuck's sake."

The door opened and a male human revealed himself, holding a mug of coffee in his free hand, his other one scratching his head under the long bronze hair and working his way down to his beard of the same color. His eyes squinted in the early morning light and his breath was still heavy as if he had just gotten up, prompting Taylor to ask if he was even prepared.

"Yeah, I got my shit together," the man whose name was McCoy answered with annoyance.

"What, did you sleep in those clothes?" Taylor chuckled.

"So what if I did?" McCoy was dressed in leather work boots going halfway up his shins with the hems of his pantlegs tied down by the laced up collars. He even had a leather bombardier jacket on and a hat string around his neck with a hat that was also possibly leather behind his back. It really didn't bother Lucas much that this guy was wearing dead animal, but he sure wouldn't like to see a reaction of a cow or a bull if they saw the guy.

"Lucas, this is ex-Army Special Forces attack chopper pilot, S. R. McCoy," SC Taylor made the introduction. "Mac, this is Lucas Willow, the soon-to-be apprentice to Brady at the research station."

"Hey, how're you doing?" McCoy extended his bare hand.

"Doing just fine," Lucas smiled in friendly manner and took the hand thinking he was an Immune. McCoy's blue eyes made contact with Lucas's in a sincere manner out of custom than anything else because his stare remained uninterested, as if Lucas was just an obligation for him to worry about.

"We both did tours in the conflict over the Amazon years back," Taylor continued, "I was a foot soldier in the Third Battalion while this guy right here flew our air support almost exclusively. He was in there longer than I was though, and despite being susceptible in all those monsoons, he never changed."

"Wait, susceptible?" Lucas recoiled his grip from the man's hand. "You mean he's Unimmune? I'm sorry, I didn't mean to--"

"Relax," McCoy spoke coolly while taking a sip from his coffee, "if I was worried about that I'd be in a full hazmat."

"Not that he wants to change--" informed Taylor, "I bet he could tell you some stories about that--but in regards to some other humans who changed if an anthro so much as breathed on them, Mac here is at least very resistant in that regard."

"Oh, okay," Lucas eased himself knowing that he had not forced someone into a transformation by accident.

"So, let's get this journey underway, Mac," Taylor spoke to his friend, "Got everything you need?"

"Yeah, just a sec." McCoy entered his room and emerged again with a Remington 870 shotgun and a rucksack in which Lucas could see the shape of a very large box.

"Is that it?" Taylor asked with bewilderment. "You're taking that big case of C&K Scotch with you?"

"I doubt anyone else is gonna bring any of the hard stuff, do you Taylor?"

"Probably not," Taylor sighed. McCoy pressed a button on the inside of his room and the retracted ladder slid down. "Hey, Lucas," Taylor turned to the horse and smiled, "make sure this lunatic does nothing stupid and comes back a human, alright?" The coyote spoke in jest, but the human still shot him an annoyed stare as he donned his shades. "He's all yours Mac."

"Yeah, right." McCoy looked at Lucas as he put the ruck on his shoulders. "Grab your stuff and haul it up and into the chopper; I wanna get up before the clouds start moving in."

"The clouds?" asked Lucas as he followed the pilot up the ladder.

"We're headed for the coast and the storms have been hitting the shore pretty hard for the last few days." Both got onto the roof and made their way to the brown Bell 206 with the words Antarctic Research Program on the side. "We have an opening to get this thing landed on our ship with a minimum in crosswinds. We've got two get there before winds pick up."

Lucas nodded and followed McCoy, who told him where he could put his stuff and that he could sit in the aircraft's left side, unlike Taylor's car. McCoy took a few minutes to go through a mental preflight checklist as the engine whined to life and the rotors began to chop at the air above. Pulling on the collective and easing forward on the cyclic, McCoy lifted the heli off the ground and they were off.

13211112211112.title: Prepare for Storms

132111122111122.content:
Well, McCoy had nailed his two hour window, landing on top of the bulk cargo carrier moored at the port and made it inside the cabins before the rain started to fall. It then became the job of the anthro deckhands to tie the Bell down by its skids and fold in the rotor blades to that the human didn't get any falling water on his Unimmune skin.

Out in the pouring rain, Lucas's clothes quickly began to soak all the way through to his short fur and his mane was dripping water down his back to the base of his equally drenched tail. It was cold out with the wind stealing away any warmth he had and made him start to shiver, but he couldn't help but pause for a long while to admire the deckhands and the longshoremen, or rather longshore animalmen now, as they worked in tandem to move the last of the large crates set along the dock onto the ship.

From above, Lucas could tell that this town was much rougher than his own with most of the buildings in disrepair and what had been the wall left with many breaches in its stone perimeter and the only effort to mend them were barricades of haphazardly stacked cars, perhaps enough to deter zombies, but not enough for any bandits that decided to climb over. Given the overall condition of the town, it was a fair bet that it was full of red-light houses, black market shops, and a haven for organized raiding parties, the kind that gave the Town Militia back home some trouble. The only portions that seemed to be upheld were the highrises and the warehouse and dock district.

In Lucas's hometown, the most activity had come from around the Wall and its gate points, the Militia having taken over the regulation of incoming and outgoing supplies. The trade of materials in Lucas's town had essentially stagnated with its self sufficient agriculture, water purification, and low-tech capabilities. Any import was mostly limited to what was scavenged from nearby towns and cities that had been completely decimated, as their society did not condone pillaging. These supplies were then distributed to where they would be the most useful, weapons to the armories, food to the storehouses, metals to the workshops, and so forth.

Here, it was apparent that the warehouse and dock district was most active with the bustle of muscular fellows continuing with remarkable speed and coordination even in the inclement weather. It was a strange contrast from the disquieting stillness that seemed to permeate the rest of the town. The iron ship on which Lucas stood held the greatest hustle on the docks with the diesel engines thrumming and eager to depart while the crew and dockers worked in concert to move the largest containers. Without power, they relied on teamwork and the ancient methods of ropes and pulleys for the loading and unloading of the shipments.

Amazingly, there were other ships still making their way into the docks by power of sails or oars to drop off their cargo before being moored for the approaching storm. Several were fishing vessels bringing in their harvest from the nigh unlimited bounty from the unregulated ocean, while others carried what might have been trades from other ports, merely scavenged materials or even the spoils of raiding parties. There were pleasure boats as well, which looked much nicer in contrast to those with blue collar men scurrying about the decks and Lucas could occasionally see their seemingly high-class occupants appear it their large, illuminated windows. They were mostly concentrated around some of the nearby warehouses that are occupied with makeshift trading companies driven by commerce operating like an ancient bazaar than a modern port. The large buildings were full of movement and promised a wide selection of goods complete with violence and sex.

Lucas's musing was suddenly interrupted by a series of shouts that could be heard coming from another part of the the ship. Several crew members not part of the muscle-powered crane teams dropped what they were doing to see what was going down, including Lucas, whose hooves clacked across the metal deck as he ran. The shouts mixed with animal cries of rage and the escalation of a skirmish could be felt in the air even before Lucas finally caught sight of the quarrel happening right beside McCoy's helicopter.

There was a red fox backed by several companions now, some bare-pawed while others had grabbed any nearby blunt instruments to fend off a group of anthros armed with bladed weapons backed against the ships railings. The surrounded anthros were much rougher than the ship's crew and must have been bandits who climbed up the side of the ship in hopes of plundering its cargo. The fox, however, had stopped the plan short when he spotted the raid and now he barked his final warning to the bandits, his pistol drawn to reinforce his intent. The group of bandits, ever defiant, hissed and spat as they retreated down over the railing. Only one, a lion with a speargun as his own weapon, stood his ground, eyes burning with hate and challenging the fox's warning. The lion let out a roar before drawing his weapon, but the fox was a step ahead and whipped his pistol up, took quick aim and squeezed off three rounds. The lion's roar was drowned by gunfire and caught short in his throat as the bullets found their mark in his center mass. His body fell back and slumped against the railing. The fox, having neutralized the threat, holstered his weapon and calmly walked over to grab the dead lion's foot-paw and heave the leg up to tip the body over the railing, letting it splash into the water below.

As Lucas looked on in horror, he did not notice someone step up behind him until his nostrils crinkled in displeasure to the stinging scent of a cigarette. He spun around to find an otter standing behind him, a peaked cap atop its head shielding its eyes from view and the lit end of a a cigarette from the rain. Further down, Lucas saw that the otter was indeed a "he" with masculine muscles rippling underneath the fur on his uncovered chest. The only other piece of clothing he wore was a pair of black shorts, concealing his pride for the sake of decency.

"Deck Officer Chase, report!" the otter bellowed past Lucas.

"Captain!" came an acknowledgement. Lucas turned back to see the fox that had downed the lion was walking towards them. "Pirates of this dock had tried to board the ship, probably to steal cargo; they showed interest in the helicopter. When approached, they showed hostility. I issued two warnings, then fired when the leader didn't stand down."

"I want you to inform the Chief Mate," the captain spoke levelly with an easy voice, "take three more men and make a thorough sweep of the ship. We leave in half an hour and I don't want any more attempts on my ship, nor do I want one of these scum-sucking parasites wormed in between the crates just to be deep-sixed later!"

"Aye, Skipper!" with that the fox ran off, calling to some crewmen.

"Ain't it both a sight and a fucking embarrassment?" Lucas spun around, realizing that the captain of the ship was speaking to him, but he did not comprehend the question. His silence was the otter's cue to elaborate. "All these ships sailing and rowing into port," he gestured with the lit cig between his furry digits, a sweeping motion towards the view of the docks, "they all serve this town, this armpit of a city, trying to piece together what's left and what'll eventually become our limping economy. And yet there," this time he gestured to the bloodstained railing, "is the beating heart of human greed that keeps it alive."

Lucas really didn't know what the captain meant by that, but he answered, "Economy has always been driven by greed and some of us might not have been born as humans, but in a way we all used to be, so I suppose that is inevitable."

The captain just snorted as if he expected that answer, while he readjusted his hat so his dark eyes could meet Lucas's. "Yeah, we're here part of this commerce as well, trading in quite the haul of the only honest salvage to come up with the remaining fuel and supplies for those guys down there in Antarctica. Men down there hiding in igloos their thinking they're doing the world a favor, and men like me standby out here while the rest of the world goes to the dogs. Well," the captain exhaled a cloud of smoke, "The more things change, the more they stay the same," his eyes stared intently at Lucas even as he mused before cutting to business; "Come on and get your stuff, we need to weigh in your gear before we leave. I'm supposed to keep you under the limits."

McCoy was just exiting the bulkhead hatch, his wide-brimmed hat secured to his head as one of his gloved hands shielded his face from the rain. He was asking about the gunshots, a question which the captain waved off to reprimand the Unimmune human for stepping into the rain, though with a much more colorful vocabulary, leading the both inside. McCoy followed with his crude banter and the captain had a laugh while the human just chuckled dryly.

"It's good that the two of you flew in earlier than expected," the captain said as he led them up to a large industrial scale, "I know the men don't like it, but I wanna shove off as soon as possible. Alright McCoy, put your bags on the scale." McCoy complied placing both his bags, one for his issued winter gear and the other for his personal belongings, in his case several bottles of liquor. The captain must have been familiar with McCoy's tendencies because he studied the numerical readout with amusement and turned to the human, "Y'know, with what's written in all this new ham-fisted paperwork, I'm technically supposed to count that chopper of yours as your gear, which," the captain turned to him with a derisive smile, "puts you a few hundred kilos over. Tell you what though, if you throw a couple of your C&K bottles my way," he pokes McCoy's bag, "and I'll make sure to misplace some zeroes."

Will McCoy part with his booze?!!
132111122111122.title: . . .And a Bottle of Scotch

1321111221111222.content:
McCoy stood staring at the captain, his bearded face scowling with disbelief while he slouched to the side with his hands in the pockets of his jacket. He did not seem perturbed by the development, though. It was probably because he had ten other bottles of the hard stuff and also that the captain had the smile that a friend that just wanted a treat for a favor that no one else would give so easily.

"Yeah, sure." McCoy smiled wryly and opened his bag and removed the lid to the wooden box within, revealing twelve green bottles with red and yellow labels. He pulled two out and handed them to the captain, who inspected and read aloud the label.

" 'Coburn and Kelly's Rare Blend of Scotch Whiskey'. This is the good stuff, not like the leprechaun piss brewed in a bathtub that you get in town." The otter spun his newly acquired bottles in his paws. He glanced at Lucas with a smirk. "Mac always gets his hands on the good stuff. He's got a lot of leverage when he has a bird and the know-how to fly it. What do you do for this lot, McCoy?" he turned to the human who had cracked a bottle for himself and took a big swig, "Assist one of the local militias, or another stint with some zombie research program?"

McCoy grimaced as he downed the stiff drink before answering, "S&D mission," confirming his work with a militia. "I was the eye in the sky while the ground pounders cleared out a small town of any walking corpses and bandits. I staked my claim to these when they found 'em," he shook his drink to indicate the case of whiskey in his pack.

"They also filled your helo up, right?"

"Yeah. Still trying to get their paws on it. Wouldn't be surprised if the new paperwork has their prints all over it." McCoy took another swig as he stared off absently.

"Ah," the captain waved his paw, "the militias want everyone who isn't part of the force to go everywhere with just the fur on their backs. Confiscating your bird is just the icing on the cake for the town that gets to throw someone green into the cockpit and let him fly circles around the dead."

Lucas cleared his throat, grabbing the attention of captain and motioning to his bags which also needed weighing in. Not that he wanted to follow through to see if he was within the boundaries of these new regulations, but mostly so he could get settled and then get to moving about the ship. And also because he didn't like the direction of badmouthing the militias that McCoy's and the Captain's conversation was taking.

The captain merely nodded and told Lucas to place them on the scales as McCoy did with his own. He said not a word while he took a moment to jot down the number that dialed out, then finally beckoning both the human and the horse to follow him with their baggage. The three of them walked further into the ship, a few turns and down a hall with few doors on either side, until further down they reached several doors placed adjacently, each one numbered.

The captain knocked on door numbered 3. "Both of you are berthing right here in number three," he said, "Make yourselves at home and I welcome you aboard my ship and I hope you enjoy your stay for the next two weeks." His arms were crossed and he delivered it quite dryly and left shortly thereafter, presumably to oversee the rest of the preparations before departure. Lucas stood there with McCoy, feeling sort of awkward around the Unimmune human pilot, who was frightfully enough an alcoholic as well. The alcohol McCoy was drinking stung at Lucas' nostrils, not used to the stench because he usually steered far from such people. Thinking past the pilot's tendencies, Lucas wondered about McCoy allegedly being susceptible to the virus despite the human wearing several articles of clothing constructed of leather, yet he was not turning into a bull.

McCoy on the other hand wasn't thinking much about the horse morph in front of him. He only spared Lucas a contemplative glance before he move into berth number three, carelessly tossing his bags into the right corner, the bottles of liquor tinkling against each other. Lucas followed McCoy inside and found that it was a very small room with a double bunk setup on the left with just enough room on the right for the two of them to stack their belongings and still have enough room to stand.

"Do you mind if I take bottom bunk?" Lucas asked mostly to break the silence between them.

"Sure, no problem," McCoy grunted as he stripped out of his heavy clothes.

"Thanks. I get kind of restless and it helps if I'm...you know, closer to the ground."

"That's good. Don't want to go rolling off the bunk and down to the ground, do you?" Out of his jacket and boots, McCoy was down to his sweater and cargoes when he walked over to the bunk and hoisted himself over the top one. He took his sombrero with him and once he was lying on his back he pulled the hat over his face to shield his eyes from the light. "I'll just be up here taking a rest."

Lucas placed his bags onto the bottom bunk, not exactly tired and feeling a bit too cramped to stay in the berth.

"Well then, I guess I'll go check out the rest of the ship, okay."

"Yeah," McCoy affirmed gruffly.

As Lucas was about to leave the human called out, "Hey, I just remembered..."

"What?" Lucas asked.

"If you see the captain, ask him if he's got some of those electronic chess consoles down in supply."

"Um, alright?" With that, Lucas left McCoy to sleep off his drunken mind.

13211112211112222.content:
Knock-knock

"Hello, Mister McCoy?" Lucas called into the closed door to his berth.

The human had locked himself inside again. It came as no surprise to Lucas who had time to realize just how reclusive a person McCoy was. Lucas was out every day on the deck running along the outer walkways, trying not to feel trapped in the cramped enclosure of the ship surrounded by the vast expanse of ocean, and in those two weeks he had rarely seen the human anywhere other than his bunk either drinking, asleep, or playing around with the chess console he got from the captain. He didn't eat very often either and always skipped breakfast, so his presence at the mess hall sparse as well. McCoy wasn't asocial though, he had to give him that. While Lucas would often try to stay clear of the groups of workers and keep only to himself, especially when that fox was around, whose name he neglected to remember, McCoy on the other hand was always conversing with the crew when he was around, often sitting stretched out in a chair with laid back expression on his face while he listened to their conversations, throwing in his quips when he deemed it appropriate.

Knock-knock-knock

"Mister McCoy, are you awake in there?"

For a while Lucas waited and was eventually able to discern an electronic voice speaking behind the locked door. McCoy was definitely attempting to defeat that computer at yet another round of chess. ". . . MY MOVE: BISHOP TO KNIGHT FOUR."

"C'mon, c'mon, we ain't got time for this," the captain appeared, padded up to Lucas and pounded impatiently at the door. McCoy, however, had other plans. He had just poured himself a drink and took a sip as he contemplated his next move and smiled as he just realized the bad move the computer had just made. McCoy ignored the knocking at his door as he tapped out in his next move, confident that in three moves he would slam his drink down in celebration for his victory.

"YOUT MOVE: PAWN TAKES QUEEN AT KNIGHT FOUR," droned the monotone female voice. "MY MOVE: KNIGHT TO ROOK THREE."

"Poor baby, you're starting to lose it, aren't you?" McCoy snickered above the rim of his glass. Another round of impatient knocking made him throw a sneer towards the locked door. He tapped in his next move and gazed expectantly at the screen.

"YOUR MOVE: KING TO ROOK ONE. MY MOVE:KNIGHT TO ROOK SIX. CHECKMATE."

That wiped McCoy's grin from his face. He glared at his electronic opponent, noting the primitive construction of a entire computer tower and monitor that were required to run this game that ran in the ten-kilobyte range and how this primitive opponent still managed to hold such and unfair score over him. Putting his hand on the monitor he leaned the whole thing backwards, giving him a good angle to pour his full glass of C&K down the machine's cooling vents, into the game's guts. Sparks spewed forth in the ensuing electric popping followed by smoke rising from the ruined circuitry.

"Cheating bitch," McCoy spat, slipping down from his bunk and mumbling his way to the door. "Yeah, what is it?"

He opened the door to see an otter and a horse looking at him expectantly. "What are you doing in here, Mac; jerking off or are you just getting plastered?"

McCoy just groaned while rubbing at his face, not in the mood to come up with some witty comeback. "Hey, you got any more of those electronic chess things?"

The captain ignored McCoy, moving past him into the room. "Lucas, get your stuff packed. Mac, get your gear on."

McCoy suddenly comprehended the interruption. "We hit the Antarctic?"

"That's right, we're already docked at Palmer," the otter affirmed. "Your chopper is fueled up and ready for takeoff. No ice buildup. Weather will be clear, but you've only got a few hours of daylight to get to your halfway checkpoint where you should receive a load up supplies for Station 4 before you continue."

"Goddamn time crunch," McCoy suddenly complained when he realized how late it was. "This is gonna turn out to be a night flight, isn't it?"

"That's why I want you up in the air in ten. You've got over a thousand miles to cross. That'll take you, what, five hours?"

McCoy nodded. "Give or take."

"If you don't dick around, you might just make it."

---------------------------------------------------------

It took less than ten minutes for Lucas and McCoy to get into the air. Their bags were stacked in the back as well as that broken chess console that McCoy dragged along. Lucas could smell the burnt circuitry, which made him wonder why McCoy even bothered. He himself had brought along something from the ship as well, or rather received it as a gift.

"What's that you got there?" McCoy took notice if the plastic box sitting on Lucas' lap even as he worked the aircraft's controls.

"Some kind of music player," Lucas answered, surprised the human actually started a conversation. "The captain told me how long and boring the flights are and gave me this." He held up the ancient piece of plastic.

"Huh," McCoy smirked. "And what kind of music do you have on it?"

"I don't know, it. . ." Lucas slumped, having a hard time admitting, "it only plays cassettes, and I've only got the captain's mixtapes."

"McCoy chuckled mockingly. "And who knows what that crazy sunvabitch's listens to..."

The captain stood below, seeing the chopper off as it circled around, gaining altitude before swinging back around, heading off into overcast skies over the mainland of Antarctica.
