132111122111122222.content:
The flight that Lucas found himself on was nonstop apart from the regular stops that occurred every couple of hours when the helo's fuel gauge was already flashing a warning. Landings only lasted a few minutes for Lucas to stretch his legs before the tanks were topped off again and on the last stop he helped stack more boxes of supplies into the rear seat of the Bell. It was the final stretch to Station 4.

McCoy did not talk much beyond the vocal notes to directed at himself, mostly griping about the darkness closing in sooner with the approach of the Antarctic winter and the winds that began to pick up to nineteen knots. Lucas could barely hear this as he didn't bother to wear the passenger's headset, but he could see McCoy struggling with the controls and the grimaces he made every time the helo was battered around by crosswinds. Instead, Lucas had the headphones from the cassette player on his ears though the contours of his equine head made it difficult when the pair were made for human heads. It was all he could do to keep his mind from the boredom of the flight, and then the terror as the second flight in his life was no longer over the calm eastern coastline but up in the violent air above the coldest region on the earth.

Unfortunately for Lucas, the tapes he had gotten from the captain were filled with nothing but ancient songs from before the turns of the last two centuries. Lucas just didn't like rock and roll and felt that it should stay as dead as the use of guitars in music, when digital sampling trumped all other forms of creativity back in 2112. At first the song he was listening to showed promise with the aged synths building an atmospheric intro, but then the guitar started to throw in it's licks. Lucas rolled his eyes in exasperation, but decided to endure this distraction rather than listen to the horrible thrumming of the rotors and howl of the wind around the cabin. It was only when the screeching vocals sang something about some Temples of Syrinx that Lucas angrily hit the fast-forward button.

Five minutes later, forms appeared in the shady white below, a few miles out. Small clusters of lights could be seen dotting the distant structures.

"This is chopper B-2. Come in Station 4," McCoy spoke into his mic.

"Station 4 here. It's about time you showed, Mac," a voice snickered through the radio.

The human ignored the comment and continued, "We are on the approach to Station 4, twelve miles out."

"You are go for approach. Landing area is clear and waiting."

As the helicopter drew near, the dark tundra gave way to reveal a grouping of small buildings covered in snow, illuminated by external lights. It was hard to see what everything was, but from the height they were at Lucas could make out what looked like a flight tower, a small hangar, several snow tread dozer vehicles parked around, and high banks of snow with a cleared section in the inside corner of the L-shaped compound, the patch that McCoy was descending on.

"Come in B-2, come in B-2. Ceiling: five-hundred feet. Visibility: Seventy yards, bring it in nice and slow," the radio operator pretended to guide the pilot down. "Just a little lower. Easy there, now. Easy does it. Five yards. . .two,one, touchdown, and it's good." The helicopter shuddered stiffly when it made contact with hard ground. Once the cyclic was down, McCoy hit a few switches which was followed the swishing blades overhead winding down when he killed the engine. "Meet you out there in a second, Mac."

Lucas stepped outside, immediately recoiling when subzero temperatures penetrated the short coat of fur on his head and stung his sensitive skin like needles. Once his hooves were on the snow covered ice, the cold spiked right up to the quick, causing him to yelp and trot in place. His bag! It had a pair of boots specifically designed for his species, courtesy of the commission. He threw open the rear door and rummaged through his pack, freezing his hooves off before he pulled out a relatively high pair of grey nylon lace-up boots, noticeably lacking in human plantigrade shape. They were heavily insulated with the circular, hoof-like sole spreading wide to accommodate walking on snow.

"Hey, s'cuse me," someone suddenly nudged past Lucas, almost tipping him over as he hopped on one hoof, trying to yank his left boot on. It was a fox with a white pelt, an arctic fox morph. He ignored Lucas and hopped into the chopper to look over the cargo boxes. As Lucas clumsily slipped on the other boot, he couldn't help but gawk at seeing this specimen in a place where it would look most natural apart from the native region of the Arctic half the globe away. "Mac! Great ta see ya again," the fox spoke to the pilot still going over his instruments. "Say, are these all the parts for the DeHavilland?"

"Yeah, I heard from the last checkpoint that the tunnel collapsed," McCoy stepped out and came around to the open door where Lucas stood, "and figured you'd get that old crate fixed so I don't have to make any long-hauls."

"Solid man, fucking solid," the fox jumped back out. "Feel like a kit on Christmas." He straitened out and stuck his hand-paws into his black leather jacket. Even an arctic fox was bundled up here with his winter camo cargoes shoved down into boots similar to Lucas' except fitted for digitigrade paws, long enough to go a little past his ankles, and adorned with buckles on the sides instead of laces. Then his hazel eyes with their slitted pupils fell on Lucas."Hah-ay! You must be the new assistant biologist, Brady's protege. Sylvan's the name." The fox offered his paw to Lucas as an afterthought to his introduction. "Assistant mechanic and junior pilot."
"Mine's Lucas," he said, taking the fox's hand. "Lucas Willow."

"Right on," Sylvan smiled toothily, giving a much firmer grip on his shake than Lucas expected and flinched in response. Sylvan noticed and eased up. "Oh, my bad."

McCoy in the meantime had his bag in hand as well as the chess console hefted over his shoulder and began to walk away from his helicopter.

"Where ya going, Mac?" Slyvan calls after the human.

"Up to my shack," McCoy answered without turning.

"Ain't you gonna show your face in the rec. room?"

"No."

"Gonna show up for grub in the morning then?"

McCoy didn't answer and kept walking.

"Eh, fuck him," Sylvan waved in the human"s direction. The fox turned his attention to Lucas. "Now that you're bot here I can go to sleep," he said and started to leave for the nearest building and the doorway shielded under a domed entrance over which shined the two brightest floodlights. Though small, it was the main entrance of the compound. Lucas grabbed his bags from the helicopter and shut the door before running after the fox who was already at the door.

Juina was sleeping in bed in her apartment. She woke up hungry, as usual with pregnant women, but she was also a horse, so she always like to eat. Concealed in the privacy of her apartment, she didn't bother to put on clothes. She went to brew some coffee and ready her feed bag under the FooDespenciTron. She went out onto her porch overlooking various scenes like, the wall guard patrolling for zombies and raiders, a small riot started by a man preaching nonsense which seemed to comprehend to the idiot people listening, and the sound of some soldier's radio contacting them. Then a ding came from her FooDespeniTron and her feed bag was filled to the brim with pancakes, waffles, eggs, syrup, etc. She set down the pot and strapped the feed bag around her head and began to eat away. She sat down on the couch and turned on the T.V. screen to the news.

A female voice came on and stated, "The Prime minister of Russia today stated that he will relocate to St Petersburg, and continue to conduct the political policies of Russia from there on out. He also stated that, '...the zombie apocalyse will not stand in the way of Russia, her way of life, and her people...' He cannot be currently reached for further questions." As she continued to consume her meal, she noticed that her bag was almost empty. So she unstrapped it and placed in under the FooDespeniTron to be refilled. She then grabbed her coffee pot and with both hands, drank it all down and placed it to brew some more coffee.

She then went over to the FooDespenciTron and waited for it to refill. A ding sound was made and the food bag was refilled to the brim with more food. She then restraped the bag to her head and proceeded to lie down on the couch and tried to wrap her hand around her round belly. As she continued to proceed to eat all the food in her bag. Just then a masculine voice came from the screen.

"The Chancellor of Germany has declared that Germany has been reclaimed from the zombies and have arrested or killed any bandits, raiders, and looters. We now go live to the City-Fortress of New Berlin for further details."

Just then a knock came from her door. She unstrapped her feed bag, which was 3/4 emptied into her belly. She then proceeded to put on her bathrobe which couldn't hide her belly and privates very well. She tried in vein to wrap the robe's belt around her belly, but even her arms couldn't wrap around it. Another knock was heard from the door. "Be right there." she proclaimed. She gave up on the bathrobe and went to answer the door. When she opened the door, a militaristic human came in.

"We're here to turn your apartment into a base of operations and use it for our own evil gains." he said jokingly.

"Grant!" Juina said, "what brings you here."

"Just ask him." Grant said and pointed to another male human surrounded by more soldiers.

"Commander," Juina said surprised. "What are you doing here?"

"I am temporarily revoking your maternity leave." the Commander stated.

"What?" Juina protested.

"Eric called and said he couldn't assist in the fortress' defenses, said he's sick. Now I'm one man short, and you know that when I'm one man short, I am not a happy man, so I need you to get ready."

"But what if I give birth while on the job?" Juina asked.

"It's not due for another 5 and a half weeks. Now get ready. I'll be waiting for you outside by the truck."

The Commander and the other soldiers all left the room followed by Grant who said to Juina, "Really like the new privates, but I like your privates." To that, Juina flipped him off. She then went to her closet and got out her military gear. She took off her bathrobe and put on some panties. She then, in vein, to put on some pants. With her belly in the way, she tried to tie them and then proceeded to put on her camo shirt, but with her belly in the way, it was hard to put her shirt on. She finally got her shirt on, but with 1/3 of her belly exposed. Juina grabbed her bandolier to put it on. Sadly, it didn't fit all the way down her torso. She grabbed her combat boots and tried to get them on, but she couldn't bend down. So she bent her legs back towards her flank to tie them. She then grabbed her pistol and assault rifle. She was ready.

Lisa awoke in the half light - the time between night and dawn. All night she kept candles alight along the windowsill, across the desk and the bedside table - electricity may be scarce these days but you couldn't take your chances in the dark - zombies were no longer a myth from a horror movie; they were real.

Wide awake, Lisa slid out of bed. Wrapping her fake fur dressing gown around her slim furry shoulders she padded down the stairs. Her old bones ached due to the cold. A sliver of moonlight illuminated the kitchen and as she opened the fridge light flooded in to the room. Careful not to catch her claws on the carton, Lisa skillfully caught the handle in her paw and tipped the white liquid in to the glass she had waiting.

Suddenly she heard a crash. It could have been the foxes exploring the bins - or it could have been something else....

Something soft and light brushed against her leg

"Sammy!"

She breathed a sigh of relief, crouching down to the ginger cat's - her pet cat's - level.

Oddly, when Lisa had agreed to the experiment she had thought it would bring her closer to understanding the mindset of one of her previous pet cats, Samuel, - now, ironically she was more physically similar to the old Sammy than she ever could have imagined was possible and yet their communication was as basic as it ever had been: Of course - Sammy was still a cat, and had died a long time ago, though his many-times removed grandchild kept her company. She was an anthro - a part cat - an ELEMENT of cat

In that moment there was a piercing scream. The candles flickered - Sammy rushed to the door as fast as her fragile body allowed her.

There was a slow, determined knock........

Between the late 21st century and the early 22nd century, two viruses had been unleashed into the world, affecting the majority of the population. One virus turned people into zombie-like creatures that craved any form of raw meat, including human flesh. There was no humanity in them. The other virus turned people into humanoid versions of animals- typically the last animal they had touched, eaten, or worn. They tended to retain their memories, and their humanity, for the most part.

It has been over a century since their release into the world. Here is what is known:

1. The two viruses are incompatible with each other- a person infected by one canât be infected by the other.

2. The viruses are mainly waterborne, carried in the water, and even in precipitation (rain, snow, sleet, hail). The safest way to make sure that oneâs drinking water is safe- especially from the more dreaded zombie virus, is by boiling it.

3. There are uninfected humans out there- some are naturally immune, others have no immunity. Some are known as âbornâ-humans- their parents were anthros, but due to certain genes they were born human.

4. Currently there is no cure- especially for the Zombie virus. Those who get the Anthro virus can live out their lives. Those turned into zombies tend to be put down.

5. Anthros can have children with other types of anthros and humans. Zombies spread by biting unimmune humans.

6. Anthros tend to age at the same rate as humans, and are prone to several of the same diseases, though they are susceptible to some of the same sorts as actual animals. Zombies last for several years, sometimes decades depending on location, and situation.

7. Normal animals are unaffected by both virus, and are unable to carry either. However, zombies will still eat them, and many are still raised for food and other items for those who eat meat.

8. What a non-immune human could turn into after coming into direct contact with tainted water depends on location- if near a place full of zombies, the person will probably turn into a zombie. If the person is in a place full of anthros, odds are theyâll turn into an anthro.

9. Zombies are typically found in the Old Cities where huge populations of people used to live, like London, New York City, San Francisco, Paris, Hong Kong, Constantinople, Rome, Tokyo, Moscow, and others. However, they have been known to wander from the area. Anthros and most surviving humans live in the New Cities, most of which are built with defense in mind.

10. Pre-virus population records amounted to 15 billion people. Current records are an estimated 8 billion zombies, 4 billion anthros, 1 million âbornâ-humans, and ten thousand âpureâ humans.

11. Zombies seem to act on very basic instincts, mainly the need to feed. They seem to lack any real intelligence, and donât seem to learn from previous mistakes or successes. However, when they see, or hear something, such as a person moving, they will go after it, and they wonât stop until they get it, even if it means their deaths. However, there is a chance- a very slim one- that they might become intelligent enough to use weapons and tactics, and more.

12. The only sure way to kill a zombie is to destroy the brain. Cutting the head off will stop the body, but the skull will continue to bite.
